Inorganic Materials and Catalysis Division, CSIR-Central Salt and Marine Chemicals Research Institute, Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR) GB Marg Bhavnagar 364 002 India NbOPO4 supported TiO2 materials were demonstrated to be excellent catalysts for selective conversion of C6-carbohydrates to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural in an environmentally benign dimethyl carbonate-water solvent system. The materials presented high activity and excellent stability in sub-critical water conditions (upto 180 °C and 20 bar), enabling continuous 5-hydroxymethylfurfural production from highly concentrated sugars (35 wt% fructose, glucose and glucose:fructose mixtures) in a micro fixed-bed reactor. The high catalytic activity (6–27.3 KgHMFKgCat −1day−1) and good-to-excellent HMF selectivity (55–91 %) and exceptional hydrolytic stability and regenerability observed under process conditions was attributed to a highly crystalline NbOPO4 phase with Q2 and Q3 phosphates stabilized on a TiO2 framework with tunable acidity (0.11–0.52 mmolH +g−1 and Brønsted/Lewis ratio) and acidic strength comparable to bulk-NbOPO4. Furthermore, our experiments also revealed the importance of organic solvents in modulating catalyst acidic properties, particularly the strength of Brønsted acid sites which, in turn, influenced the HMF productivity. It can be obtained from the abundantly available C6 carbohydrate fraction from various biomass (e.g. cellulose, starch, inulin). Further, it offers a unique value chain owning to its diverse multifunctional structure and can undergo various organic transformations including hydrogenation, hydrogenolysis, oxidation, decarbonylation, etherification, hydration, aldol condensation, polymerization and so-forth to produce various high-value products of commercial importance such as 5-methyl furfural, 5-methyl-2-furan methanol, 2,5-dimethylfuran, 1,2,6-hexanetriol, 1,6-hexanediol, 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl furan, 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid, 2,5-diformyl furan, dimethyl tetrahydrofuran and others. Thus, HMF production is a highly sought-after process considering potential market opportunities for both HMF and its derivatives [1]. Technically HMF synthesis is a well-known process, and can be synthesized by the dehydration of C-6 carbohydrates in the presence of strong homogenous (e.g. H2SO4, AlCl3, HCl) or heterogeneous acids (e.g. sulfated resins, sulfated metal oxides, acidic zeolites) as catalysts [1,2] ( Scheme 1). However, its production in high yield and/or selectivity is very challenging due to several factors which include formation of byproducts such as levulinic acid and formic acid by rehydration, formation of partially dehydrated products, polymerization of HMF to humins at high temperature as well as other unknown products. In other words, due to its chemical instability HMF formation competes with various non-linear/parallel reactions promoting HMF degradation. Further, complications also arise due to the poor miscibility of carbohydrates in most known organic solvents, which necessities the use water as solvent/reaction media which is known to accelerate formation of unwanted polymeric byproducts like humins, which in addition to HMF yield also impact catalyst performance negatively (active site poisoning). In recent years, HMF yield (or selectivity) has been increased substantially through reactive extraction using biphasic media comprising water as the reactive layer and a non-miscible organic solvent such as methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK) [3], methyl tetrahydrofuran, butanol [4] tetrahydrofuran (THF) [5], and γ-valerolactone (GVL) [6] as the extracting layer over both homogeneous as well as heterogeneous catalysts. In addition, water-organic biphasic systems containing salts have also been employed to promote the so-called salting-out effect (deliberate addition of Na and K salts to the reactive aqueous layer can minimize solubilization of reacting aqueous and extracting organic layers, thereby leading to suppressed HMF degradation) [7]. Even so, a major drawback of such approach is due to the use of large volumes of extracting organic solvents (4:1–10:1 (w/w) organic to aqueous ratio) to afford good HMF recovery, which leads to increased product cost as additional downstream purification steps and solvent recovery becomes unavoidable [8]. Improved HMF yield/selectivity have also been obtained in molten salts such as tetraethylammonium bromide (TEAB) [9,10], LiNO3–NaNO3–KNO3 (LSP) [11], quaternary ammonium salts [12], ionic liquids as well as dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) due to their stabilizing effects on HMF [13]. However, use of such salts, ionic liquids and sulfur containing solvents is undesirable as they negatively impact the catalyst lifetime, HMF recovery as well its purity/quality. In fact, several studies have recently highlighted the importance of trace impurities from solvents and catalysts on downstream HMF valorization, whereupon both trace organic and sulfur impurities are clearly shown to negatively impact the performance of catalysts employed in downstream conversion steps [14,15]. Generally, the use of homogeneous catalysts has some inherent disadvantages which include requirement of complicated downstream purification steps to separate the catalyst from products, including distillation, neutralization, solvent extraction etc. To avoid such problems, various heterogeneous catalysts have also been introduced in recent years (e.g. acidic resins, mixed oxides, acidic zeolites, phosphated, sulfated metal oxides). However, the development of efficient, inexpensive and robust heterogeneous catalysts capable of achieving high conversion efficiency and high HMF yield/selectivity from concentrated carbohydrate streams has remained elusive. This is mainly due to formation of byproducts such as humins on the catalyst surface which results in fast catalyst deactivation [16–20]. In addition, cation exchange of acidic protons (in the presence of salts), acid site leaching and degradation of solid materials in hot pressurized liquid water also contribute considerably to the loss of catalyst activity (e.g. dealumination and collapse of framework occurs when using zeolitic catalysts) [21,22]. Among the various solid acid catalysts reported in literature, phosphated catalysts based on water stable oxides such Nb, Ti and W have in recent years gained considerable attention due to the combination of their unique acidic properties (desirable acidic strength and tunable Brønsted/Lewis acidity) and good-to-excellent stability under hydrothermal conditions. For example, Hara and co-workers reported the excellent catalytic performance of a phosphoric acid-treated Nb2O5·nH2O (i.e. H3PO4/Nb2O5·nH2O) affording high HMF yield from glucose, which was ca. 4.3-fold higher than the yield obtained over pristine Nb2O5·nH2O, the catalyst also retained its activity recycled upto 5-times without any loss of catalytic performance [23,24]. In another, work Hensen and co-workers reported the application of Nb-containing tungstite as well as their phosphated counterparts as an effective, recyclable heterogeneous catalyst for HMF production from glucose and fructose, affording HMF yield in range of 34–58 % [25]. Similarly, Yue and co-workers reported the application of various supported and unsupported phosphated TiO2 as a bifunctional catalyst for HMF production from fructose and glucose in yields approaching as high as 66–71 % in both batch as well as flow reactors [26,27]. However, it has been recently shown by Xu et al. that such phosphated TiO2 catalysts undergo rapid deactivation when using concentrated (10 wt% or greater) carbohydrates as the substrate at temperatures above 175 °C, due to considerable deposition of organic matter as well as phosphate leaching from the catalyst [28]. The improved performance of the phosphated TiO2 catalyst reported by Yue et al. is mainly attributed to the usage of highly diluted (1–2 wt%) substrates as feedstock [26,27]. Although inexpensive sulfonic resin-based catalysts have also been employed as effective catalysts for HMF production, they suffer from issues such as S-leaching, poor stability in hot liquid water and regenerability which makes them less attractive for large scale applications [29]. To summarize, till date there are no known large-scale processes (pilot or commercial scale) producing HMF with solid (heterogenous) acid technology. In fact, the only commercial HMF process developed by AVA Biochem utilizes a modified hydrothermal technology which require the use of purified fructose as substrate, sulfuric acid as the catalyst and methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK) as the extracting solvent, respectively [30]. Nevertheless, considering the inherent advantages of solid acid catalysts significant scope still exists further advancement HMF production through judicious development catalytic materials with features (low-cost, robust, activity, and selectivity) which can enable intensified HMF production in flow/fixed-bed reactor using the various commercially available concentrated sugar as feedstocks (e.g. fructose, glucose, sucrose and high fructose corn syrup). Next to catalyst, selection of extracting organic solvent plays perhaps the most important role as it influences the obtained HMF yield by controlling the interplay between reactions responsible for HMF formation and HMF degradation [31–34]. Upon simple in-situ extraction of unstable furanic products (e.g. HMF, furfural) from the reactive (usually aqueous) to the organic phase in a biphasic system, suppresses the acid promoted degradation pathways (Scheme 1). Among the various extracting solvents reported, ketonic solvents (such as MIBK, dimethyl carbonate, GVL, acetone) and DMSO have been reported to show the best performance (in terms of increasing HMF selectivity/yield) owing to their ability to form hydrogen bonding interactions with the furan functional groups, resulting in suppression of undesirable rehydration, aldol condensation and humin forming polymerization pathways [32]. In addition to product extraction, solvent selection can also impact catalyst performance as it can also influence key parameters like acidity, and stability [35,36]. However, in the context of green chemistry, solvent selection in terms of combined performance, environmental, health and safety (EHS) impacts and subsequent downstream processing is more important rather than performance alone, and is expected to have major impact on viability of developed process [18,19,31–33]. Within this study our main goal is to develop an improved continuous catalytic process for HMF production from various concentrated C6 carbohydrate streams using noble NbOPO4 supported TiO2 as a recyclable solid acid catalyst and environmentally benign dimethyl carbonate-water solvent system. The catalyst selection is motivated by the well documented acidic properties of Nb based solid materials which exhibit the desirable acidic strength, bifunctionality (Brønsted/Lewis acidity) and the stability of Nb and Ti oxides in hot-pressurized (subcritical) water, as well as our recent efforts depicting feasibility of synthesizing such supported NbOPO4 catalysts [22,37–40]. Further, the use of supported Nb catalysts which contain 80–90 % less Nb than their bulk counterparts, can also address the drawback associated with the high cost of Nb (natural abundance ca. 20 ppm) while solvent selection is motivated by CHEM21 selection guide as well as the recently reported efficacy of a dimethyl carbonate-water biphasic solvent system for HMF production with homogenous acids [32–34]. Also, considering the importance of extracting organic solvents in modulating acidity and stability of solid acids, herein we have also critically explored the role of solvents upon catalytic performance [35,36]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of supported Nb catalysts All reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. TiO2 supported NbOPO4 catalysts were prepared by direct precipitation of NbOPO4 onto TiO2 supports under acidic conditions using NbCl5 as the Nb precursor and (NH4)H2PO4 as the phosphate source. An illustrative example depicting preparation of 20 %NbOPO4/TiO2 is as follows: 3.5 g NbCl5 was dissolved in 50 ml conc. HCl (12 M) at room temperature (27 °C), followed by addition of 6 g TiO2 powder (ottokemi) and stirring the contents at room temperature for 1 h. To the above mixture a solution containing 7 g (NH4)H2PO4 dissolved in 70 ml conc. HCl (12 M) was added dropwise, while keeping the mixture under constant stirring. The resulting mixture was further stirred at room temperature for 5 h, followed by aging the contents in a polypropylene bottle at 80 °C for 48 h. Next the solid contents of polypropylene bottle were recovered by filtration, followed by washing with deionized water (until free from chloride), drying in an oven at 100 °C overnight (10 h), followed by crushing and calcination at 500 °C for 6 h under static air in a muffle furnace to obtain 20 %NbOPO4/TiO2. To obtain 20 %Nb2O5 supported on TiO2 the phosphate source i.e. (NH4)H2PO4 was replaced with deionized water. The detailed variations in synthetic procedures adapted leading to different catalytic materials are summarized in Table S1, supporting information. 2.2 Preparation of catalyst extrudates Catalysts were shaped into pellets having the dimensions (3 mm×5 mm, D×L), for which the catalyst powder prepared in Example 1–2, were mixed with organic binder (hydroxyethylcellulose 4500–6500 mPa∙s) in 70:30 (w/w) ratio, and the resulting paste extruded through an extruder. The obtained extrudates were cut into desired length (5 mm) and further calcined at 500 °C for 6 h under static air in a muffle furnace to obtain the shaped catalysts. Use of well-known inorganic binders such as alumina and boehmite were avoided as it led to materials with altered acid-base properties which were catalytically inactive for HMF production. 2.3 Catalyst characterization All catalytic materials were extensively characterized to evaluate their surface, textural, acidic, chemical composition, structural and morphological properties. The surface acidity (quantity and strength) of catalytic materials were evaluated by NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and pyridine probe FT-IR techniques. Specific surface area, pore size and pore volumes were obtained from N2-physisorption measurements. Structure, morphology and microstructure was investigated by powder X-ray Diffraction (XRD), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). The surface elemental compositions were investigated by Energy Dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). The thermal stability of the catalytic materials was studied by Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) under N2 atmosphere. The spent and spent-regenerated catalysts were also analogously characterized to evaluate the compositional, morphological or textural changes occurring in the material during reaction conditions. The specific details of the different procedures employed for the characterization of catalytic materials are given in supporting information. 2.4 Catalytic reaction procedures Preliminary benchmarking experiments in batch mode were conducted using SS316 micro-batch reactors (∼13 ml) assembled from high pressure tube fitting (Panam Engineers Ltd., India). In a typical experiment: fructose/glucose or other suitable C6 sugar (0.88 g), catalyst (30–70 mg catalyst), 2.5 ml dimethyl carbonate and 2.5 ml deionized water were charged in the micro-reactor vessel. Next, the reactor was sealed up at room temperature (27 °C) and the contents and stirred vigorously (1100 rpm) to dissolve the sugars. Thereafter, the reactor was placed in a preheated oil bath at desired reaction temperature (150–180 °C) for the desired duration of reaction (15–240 min) under magnetic stirring and autogenous pressure (measured as 10 bar). All batch experiments were performed at a high stirring rate of (1100 rpm) using small particles (<50 µm) to minimize inter and intra particle diffusion effects. To quench the reaction SS reactor was taken out from the oil batch and placed under cold tap water. After cooling, the reactor was carefully opened and the contents of organic and aqueous layer separated by centrifugation (6000 rpm,10 min) and analyzed. All batch experiments are conducted in duplicate and the conversion, yield reported are average of two experiments. For catalytic experiments in flow, a customized horizontal fixed-bed micro reactor (FBR) having an internal diameter of 10 mm, a length of 100 mm and a volume of ca. 7.5 ml was used. The reactor inlet was connected to a HPLC pump (SSI Series II) while the system pressure was maintained using a back-pressure regulator (BPR) (Jordan valve) ( Scheme 2). In a typical flow experiment, the catalyst bed was packed with 1.2 g of the catalyst pellets which were supported on each end by glass wool and two 2 µm stainless steel (SS316) frits. Next, the reactor was slowly pressurized to 20 bar under constant (0.05 ml/min) flow of deionized H2O and after stabilization of system pressure reactor heated to the desired reaction temperature (150–180 °C) and the emulsified feed comprising carbohydrate (fructose, glucose or glucose:fructose mixture) in 1:1 (v/v) dimethyl carbonate:water bi-phasic system (carbohydrate conc. in aq. phase was 35 wt%) was fed at a constant flow rate to achieve the desired weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 6–20 h−1. Herein, the use a of simplified single pump system was feasible due to the good solubility of dimethyl carbonate (ca. 130 g/L) in water and the use of low organic to aqueous ratio 1 (v/v). At the outlet connected downstream to BPR the product stream comprising of HMF, unreacted carbohydrate, and other minor products are collected in a collector connected downstream to FBR and periodically analyzed. The reaction products from both batch and flow experiments were analyzed after appropriate work up (centrifugal separation, passing through 0.2 µm nylon syringe filter and dilution) by HPLC on a Thermo Scientific UltiMate 3000 system equipped with RefractoMax520 RI detector and also an Aminex HPX-87 H column (5 Millimolar H2SO4 was used as the eluent) at 50 °C. Herein, we have designed novel Nb- supported TiO2 catalysts containing well dispersed, but highly crystalline and strongly acidic Nb (NbOPO4) phase with stable Q2 and Q3 type tetrahedral phosphates bonded to Nb atom. The presence of well crystallized and dispersed NbOPO4 phase, was expected to suppress (or eliminate) the possibility of crystallization as well as leaching induced irreversible acidity loss typically reported to be responsible for deactivation of such catalysts (see below) [37–39,42,43]. The comparison of XRD patterns of as synthesized NbOPO4 supported TiO2 catalysts with the reference TiO2 and NbOPO4 materials, confirm the presence of a well-defined, crystalline NbOPO4 phase along with the anatase TiO2 phase in the supported catalysts (JCPDS NO. 70–2648 and JCPDS no. 00–021–1272) supporting the successful incorporation of NbOPO4 particles of varying crystallinity on TiO2 support ( Fig. 1(a)). In contrast, for Nb2O5 supported TiO2 obtained in the absence of phosphate source the characteristic NbOPO4 peaks were absent (Figure S1, supporting information) [44]. Furthermore, the XRD patterns of supported NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts exposed to reaction conditions for extended duration (>24 h) also exhibited the characteristic peaks of NbOPO4 as well as TiO2 phase similar to those of pristine materials and the reference sample consistent with the effectiveness of developed synthetic protocol (direct precipitation NbOPO4 under acidic conditions) for obtaining sub-critical water stable solid acids (Fig. 1(b)). From the data presented in Fig. 1(a-b), it is also clearly seen that the NbOPO4/TiO2 material presented excellent stability at temperatures upto 180 °C in hot liquid water, at 20 bar pressure (24–36 h). However, beyond 180 °C, the NbOPO4 structure was shown to collapse with considerable removal of PO4 moieties (P leaching in ICP-MS, see below) as also indicated by the substantial reduction of surface P/Nbratio, and the disappearance of characteristic NbOPO4 peaks in XRD of sample treated at 200 °C. Overall, our findings indicated good-to-excellent stability of the developed TiO2 based acidic materials under reaction conditions or operational window (150–180 °C and 20 bar) typically used in acid catalyzed dehydration of sugars to furanics (Fig. 1(a-b)). Furthermore, the XRD patterns also confirmed the presence of a well-defined anatase TiO2 in all the supported catalysts consistent with the stability of TiO2 phase under synthetic as well as operational conditions (Fig. 1(a-b)). The presence of anatase phase TiO2 and NbOPO4 phase was also supported by laser Raman measurements (shown for select samples) exhibiting the characteristic B1g, A1g, Eg peaks of TiO2 (anatase) and NbO, PO4 bands of NbOPO4 (Fig. 1(c)) [40,44,45]. The presence of NbOPO4 in NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts were also supported by the appearance of sharp bands around 585, 633 cm−1 and 1033 cm−1 respectively in the FT-IR spectra, which could be assigned to the characteristic, Ti-O-Nb, Nb-O-P/P-OH and stretching vibrations of phosphate species in NbOPO4 (Fig. 1(d)). The XPS analysis of NbOPO4/TiO2 materials indicated the presence of Nb, P, Ti and O elements on the surface with P/Nbratio ≥ 1, supporting with the presence of Q2 and Q3 type tetrahedral phosphates (Fig. 1(e)). The presence of such highly stable Q2 and Q3 type tetrahedral phosphates bound to Nb atoms in the catalytic materials was also confirmed by the presence of strong resonance peaks of characteristic crystalline NbOPO4 around 23–24 ppm (with respect to 85 % aq. H3PO4) in the 31P-MAS NMR (Fig. 1(f)) [40]. Further, the high resolution Nb3d of NbOPO4/TiO2 showed that the Nb 3d5/2 photoelectron lines appear at slightly higher binding energies i.e. 207.2–207.7 eV than those typically reported for bulk phase NbOPO4 materials appearing around 207 eV, consistent with the presence of a interaction between Nb and Ti phases in the supported material most likely through Ti-O-Nb linkages similar to the Si-O-Nb linkages reported upon NbOPO4/SiO2 materials in our previous works (Figure S1, supporting information and Fig. 1(e) inset). Similarly, the P2p peaks also appeared at higher binding energy (133.6–133.7 eV) than those reported for bulk phase NbOPO4 at 133.0 eV [38–40]. Most importantly, these materials even after exposure to the harsh reaction/process conditions of hot liquid water at 150–180 °C and multiple regeneration/calcination cycles (at 500 °C for 5 h), also retained the characteristic features of Nb 3d5/2 and P2p3/2 in XPS and maintained the P/Nbratio ∼1, consistent with the robustness of developed crystalline NbOPO4 supported TiO2 catalysts under hot subcritical water conditions (Fig. 1, Figure S1, supporting information and Table 1). In contrast, the binding energy values of Nb 3d5/2 and P2p peaks of the material exposed to subcritical water at temperature of 200 °C shifted to lower values of 207.07 and 133.3 eV, respectively consistent with the loss of acidic phosphates as also indicated by a corresponding decrease in the intensity of P2p peak as well as the surface P/Nbratio ∼0.26 (see Section 3.3 below and Figure S1, supporting information). The analysis of NbOPO4/TiO2 by TGA in N2 atmosphere reveled no major weight loss events upto 750 °C and in strong agreement with the excellent thermal stability of the catalytic materials developed herein ( Fig. 2(a)); similar, TGA patterns were also obtained for spent and spent-regenerated materials, consistent with the experimentally observed robustness of the developed NbOPO4 supported TiO2 catalysts under operational and regeneration conditions (see-below). The analysis of surface morphology of synthesized catalytic materials by SEM showed a coarse particle morphology comprising of small sphere like particles (0.5–5 µm) (Fig. 2(b-c)) while and EDX microelement mapping showed non-single cluster and uniform distribution of elements Nb, Ti, and P, consistent with the presence of well-dispersed NbOPO4 particles on the TiO2 support (Figure S2, supporting information). Further examination of pore architecture of catalytic materials with TEM revealed a non-porous structure consisting of aggregated Ti and Nb particles of sphere-rod like shapes. Moreover, HRTEM images of NbOPO4/TiO2 revealed the characteristic lattice fringes with d spacing values of 0.32 nm and 0.35 nm corresponding to the (200) and (101) planes of NbOPO4 and anatase TiO2 phase, respectively (Fig. 2(d-f)) [44]. Most importantly, these characteristic lattice fringes were also present in the spent catalytic material exposed to harsh reaction conditions (170 °C and 20 bar) for extended periods of time (time on stream >24 h) (see below), in agreement with the findings of XRD and further confirming the stability of developed catalysts for applications in sub-critical (hot-pressurized-liquid) water. The textural and acidic properties of the different NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts are summarized in Table 1, which indicated that all materials presented a low porosity with specific surface area less than 60 m2/g, which was comparable to the pristine supports. In terms of total acidity, among the NbOPO4/TiO2 series the density of acidic sites increased with increasing NbOPO4 loading and was found to be ca. 4.3-fold higher than a reference Nb2O5/TiO2 material with identical Nb loading. However, for the same NbOPO4 loading the concentration, distribution of acid sites i.e. Brønsted/Lewis (B/L) acidity, strong (S), medium (M) and weak (W) acidity and crystallinity of NbOPO4/TiO2 varied substantially as a function of synthetic conditions employed (Table 1 and Fig. 3). Specifically, the amount of H2O used in catalyst preparation directly influenced the concentration and distribution of acidic sites as indicated by the values of total acidity, B/L ratio, (S+M)/W ratio presented in Table 1. In other words, the synthetic method established herein allowed easy tuning of acidic properties (in particular Brønsted/Lewis acidity), by simple adjustment of amount of H2O (i.e·H2O/HCl ratio) used in material synthesis, thus enabling scalable production of a diverse range of acidic and bifunctional NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 3). Representative NH3-TPD profiles and, corresponding deconvolution of the TPD patterns showing W, M and S peaks for the NbOPO4/TiO2 is presented in Fig. 3(a-b), wherein the desorption peak centered around ∼200 °C corresponded to weak acid sites (Nb2O5 phase), the peak corresponding to the strong acid sites (NbOPO4 phase) was centered around 330 −340 °C, while the peak corresponding to medium sites (niobic acid phase) was between 200 and 330 °C, Fig. 3(b). Similar, trends were also obtained from pyridine FTIR measurements whereupon materials obtained under strongly acidic conditions (i.e. low H2O/HCl ratio) presented a higher (B/L) ratio consistent with the presence of a crystalline a well-defined NbOPO4 phase in the obtained NbOPO4/TiO2 material (representative spectra shown in Fig. 3(c) for NbOPO4/TiO2, Nb2O5/TiO2 and TiO2 exhibiting the characteristic Brønsted and Lewis acid peaks of chemisorbed pyridine at 1490 cm−1 and 1450 cm−1 respectively) (Table 1) [40]. This variation in distributions of B/L, S, M and W sites are attributed to the compositional variation in Nb phase i.e. relative abundance of Nb2O5 and NbOPO4 phases in NbOPO4/TiO2 which was largely dependent on the synthetic conditions (Table 1 and Fig. 3(d)). It has been postulated that under aqueous conditions (i.e. high H2O/HCl ratio) the Nb precursor (NbCl5) can readily hydrolyzed to inert/stable Nb(OH)5, which under synthetic conditions do not react with the phosphate source (NH4H2PO4), but rather converts to the corresponding oxide phase (Nb2O5 or Nb2O5·H2O) upon calcination forming the weakly acidic low-coordinated Nb5+ Lewis sites and/or weakly Brønsted acidic -Nb-OH sites ( Scheme 3) (representative XRD patterns for Nb2O5 and Nb2O5/TiO2 are included in Figure S1, supporting information) [40]. From the data in Table 1 and Fig. 3(a-c), it is also interesting to note that introduction of Nb2O5 on TiO2 surface didn’t increase total surface acidity but led only to redistribution of B/L sites with formation of new Brønsted acidic sites at the expense of Lewis sites, this could be attributed mainly to the low porosity of TiO2 support used, low Nb loading and low pH in synthetic conditions that leads to the coverage of acidic Ti-O-OH sites with Nb precursor, which upon hydrolysis forms a TiO2 framework uniformly coated with Nb2O5. Further, the strength of acidic sites measured for a NbOPO4/TiO2 sample in terms of NH3 heat of desorption was found to be 183 kJ/mol (calculated using Murakami-Tanwa method) (Fig. 3(e)) [41]. Nevertheless, NH3 desorption energy (E a) based on a simplified 1st order kinetics was 198.6 kJ/mol comparable to the previously reported value of 203 kJ/mol for NbOPO4/SiO2 but slightly less than that of bulk phase crystalline NbOPO4 (219 kJ/mol) also obtained from 1st order desorption kinetic experiments (Figure S3, supporting information) [38–40]. To further benchmark the strength of Brønsted acidic sites in NbOPO4/TiO2 we also measured and compared the Hammett acidity function (H 0) of solid acids used in the study using UV-Visible method [46,47]. The trend of Hammett acidity function (H 0) obtained for solid acids showed good agreement with the NH3 heat of desorption/adsorption values, supporting the order of strength solid acids as sulfated resins (Amberlyst 70)>NbOPO4 >NbOPO4/TiO2>NbOPO4/ZrO2>Nb2O5/TiO2 >Nb2O5>TiO2 (Fig. 3(f) and Table S3, supporting information) [37,38,40,48–51]. 3.2 Catalytic results 3.2.1 Batch screening and solvent benchmarking In order to evaluate the efficacy of developed NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts and benchmark its performance with known solid acids like TiO2, ZrO2, NbOPO4, Nb2O5, Nb2O5/TiO2 and Amberlyst 70, preliminary catalytic tests were conducted in batch mode at 170 °C under autogenous pressure in the proposed 1:1 dimethyl carbonate-water biphasic solvent system using 35 wt% aqueous fructose as model substrate. The results from batch experiments presented in Table 2, confirm the high efficacy of NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts which was superior to bulk phase NbOPO4, TiO2, ZrO2, Nb2O5, Nb2O5/TiO2 and Amberlyst 70. Furthermore, owing to the optimum (moderate) acidic strength of NbOPO4 phase, it didn’t promote hydrolysis of dimethyl carbonate, in contrast the use strongly acidic sulfated resin (Amberlyst 70) promoted considerable hydrolysis of dimethyl carbonate which was confirmed by the presence of methanol in reaction mixture. Subsequent, comparison of TOF and selectivity trends in Table 2 revealed important role of surface acidic properties; whereupon catalysts presenting optimum balance of surface acidity and acidic strength presented the best performance in terms of activity and HMF selectivity (viz. 10 %NbOPO4/TiO2, 20 %NbOPO4/TiO2 and bulk phase NbOPO4). Nevertheless, it is to be emphasized herein that HMF selectivity in the desirable organic layer was typically half of the total selectivity for all catalysts, which is a limitation of dimethyl carbonate based biphasic system as it can complicate HMF recovery from aqueous layer (especially in the presence of unreacted carbohydrates) (Table 2). Moreover, in the proposed 1:1 (v/v) dimethyl carbonate-water biphasic solvent system, the total HMF selectivity reached its maximum at low-moderate sugar conversion, after which it dropped sharply, especially when using fructose as substrate ( Figs. 4(a) and 4(b)). This sharp decrease in HMF selectivity at higher sugar conversion was attributed to the accelerated humin formation and humin deposition on catalyst surface, as also evident from the TGA patterns of spent catalyst and optical images of reaction mixtures collected at different time intervals whereupon visible catalyst fouling was present on catalyst particles collected at 120 min. This phenomenon of accelerated humin formation at high sugar conversion was most likely consequence of phase inversion (attributed to the reduced density of aqueous layer and increased density of organic layer), which caused the extracting organic layer to move to lower layer and aqueous layer to upper layer thereby increasing contact between HMF and the acidic catalyst promoting humin forming polymerization pathways, leading to a decrease in HMF selectivity/yield and increasing catalyst fouling (Figure S4(a), supporting information). Despite these limitations the advantage of NbOPO4 supported TiO2 catalysts and dimethyl carbonate-water based biphasic solvent for selective HMF production was undeniable considering its high throughput at moderate to low sugar conversion (Table 2 and Fig. 4(a-b)). Although these catalysts operated at temperatures much higher than those reported in prior art (i.e. >150 °C), the requirement of high temperature is mainly due to solvent selection (see below) [16–27]. In view of the excellent catalytic performance of 20 %NbOPO4/TiO2 it was further used for benchmarking of different solvent systems using fructose as the model substrate which shows that among the different solvent systems tested dimethyl carbonate-water afforded the highest HMF selectivity (organic as well as total) (Fig. 4(c)). However, in terms of fructose conversion, the catalyst presented best performance in water while in the dimethyl carbonate-water system the same catalyst presented lowest activity. Overall in terms of HMF selectivity and yield polar aprotic oxygenated solvents like DMC, THF and MIBK afforded the best performance, while HMF selectivity was lowest for neat aqueous reaction. To further investigate the role of organic solvent in catalyst performance we also correlated solvent properties with conversion, HMF selectivity and yield. Comparison of solvent properties in Table S2, supporting information with catalytic data revealed a strong correlation, especially between solvent dielectric constant and aqueous solubility of extracting organic solvents with catalyst performance (Fig. 4(d) and Figure S4(b), supporting information). It is likely that in polar aprotic solvents with CO group (dimethyl carbonate, MIBK), the reactions leading to HMF degeneration (rehydration/polymerization) and by-product formation are considerably suppressed due to the stabilizing effects of CO group present in such solvents on the HMF formyl [34]. Moreover, considering the established role of organic solvents in modulating the acidic properties (strength of acids) by virtue of proton solvation, we also measured and compared the Hammett acidity function (H 0) of 20 %NbOPO4/TiO2 in the different organic solvents used in the study (using UV visible spectroscopy). Interestingly, when H 0 values were compared with the solvent dielectric constant we observed a positive correlation between increasing acidic strength and increasing solvent dielectric constant, similar to trends typically reported for pKa (acidic strength) and dielectric constants for of homogeneous Brønsted acids. These experimental findings further substantiate the role of solvents in modulating acidic properties of solid acids and consistent with the experimentally observed trends of activity and selectivity reported herein (Fig. 4(e)) [35,52–54]. To summarize, overall to achieve high HMF selectivity a polar aprotic solvent with optimum combination of dielectric properties and aqueous miscibility was required (Figure S4(b), supporting information). In other words, our experimental findings suggest that in addition to their recognized role in aiding extraction and stabilization of furanic products (e.g. HMF, furfural), organic solvents can also have a marked impact on the acidic properties of catalyst used (especially strength of Brønsted acidic sites) as solvents can strongly contribute to proton stabilization by virtue of proton solvation, which in turn influences its performance significantly impacting both activity as well as furanic product selectivity [55–57]. Overall, it is likely that in a low di-electric CO containing solvent with good miscibility in water such as dimethyl carbonate, Brønsted acid strength of solid acid catalyst are considerably lowered (less favored deprotonation due to reduced proton solvation) in reactive aqueous layer which results in suppression of the strong Brønsted acid catalyzed pathways responsible for HMF degradation (i.e. rehydration and furnaic polymerization) resulting in improved yield/selectivity of furanic product. However, use of large excess of dimethyl carbonate was found to cause suppression of even the desirable dehydration pathways attributed to the substantial increase in concentration of dimethyl carbonate in reactive layer that significantly reduced Brønsted acidic strength of 20 %NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 4(f)). 3.2.2 Catalyst reusability in batch and substrate effects In view of the promising results obtained upon selective dehydration of fructose to HMF in 1:1 (v/v) dimethyl carbonate-water biphasic solvent, subsequently we examined the operational stability (reusability) of NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts, at moderate conversion, the results of which are summarized in Fig. 5(a-b). As can be depicted in data presented in Fig. 5(a-b), the catalyst maintained good operational stability when employed at 170 °C showing only marginal reduction in HMF yield (attributed mainly to catalyst fouling due to strong adsorption of unreacted sugars and HMF). However, when the catalyst was used with intermittent calcination at 500 °C for 5 h, its performance was regained completely (90–100 %) and remained unchanged upto 5 cycles supporting the robustness of the active acid sites in the developed catalyst and consistent with the effective regeneration of catalyst during calcination step (attributed to removal of adsorbed organic impurities). Most importantly, during successive recycling steps, no leaching of Nb, Ti or P was recorded (small amount P/phosphate loss ca. 20 ppm observed in the 1st cycle and 15 ppm in the 2nd cycle was attributed to the removal of loosely bound and weakly acidic physisorbed/Q1 type phosphates, as also evident from XPS and XRD results). As expected, when the active catalyst exposed to subcritical water at 200 °C (24 h) was employed upon fructose dehydration under identical conditions, a substantial drop in its catalytic performance was observed, consistent with the experimental findings of XRD and XPS and ICP-MS and supporting the stability window of the developed catalysts in sub-critical water at temperatures upto 180 °C (Fig. 1(b), Fig. 5(b), Figure S1 and Figure S5, supporting information). Furthermore, to test the versatility of the developed catalyst, it was also examined for its potential upon HMF production from glucose, glucose-fructose mixture (1:1 wt/wt) as well as other well-known C6 carbohydrates such as inulin, sucrose, starch and cellulose using the same dimethyl carbonate-water biphasic solvent systems. The results presented in Figure S6, supporting information and Fig. 4(a-b) showed that upon substitution of fructose with glucose, a substantial suppression in HMF yield and selectivity was observed, which can be attributed to the limiting glucose to fructose isomerization step. Nevertheless, upon increasing catalyst amount or when using a mixture of fructose with glucose, reasonable improvement in HMF yield/ selectivity was possible. The increased HMF yield with an increase in the catalyst amount was attributed to the increased concentration of Lewis acidic sites in the reaction system, improving isomerization rate. Among polysaccharides, highest HMF yields were obtained for inulin due to its high fructose content while for glucose rich carbohydrates such as starch, cellulose and sucrose, the HMF yields were substantially lower under comparable conditions (Figure S6, supporting information), attributed to the inability of the developed moderately acidic catalyst to promote beta glycosidic cleavage and glucose isomerization (low concentration of Lewis acidic sites). 3.2.3 Catalytic activity under continuous flow After confirming the utility and stability of the developed NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst for HMF production from C6 monosaccharides (glucose and starch) in a stirred batch reactor, we attempted to further improve the efficiency of HMF production by attempting intensification in continuous flow using a micro fixed-bed reactor (FBR). All preliminary catalytic experiments in flow were conducted using palletized 20 % NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst (3 mm×5 mm, D×L) in a custom-made lab scale horizontal FBR at 20 bar (refer to Section 2.4) using fructose as the model C6 sugar substrate keeping all other reaction parameters similar to those of batch operation. Reaction pressure was set at 20 bar to keep all components of the reaction mixture in liquid phase. Table 3 summarizes the performance of the 20 %NbOPO4/TiO2 under different operational conditions, which shows the high efficacy of the developed catalyst for continuous HMF production under intensified conditions in an FBR. Furthermore, similar to the trends observed in batch mode, the use of Amberlyst 70 in an FBR also promoted severe hydrolysis of dimethyl carbonate (organic extracting solvent), which resulted in a substantial reduction in HMF selectivity when compared to the NbOPO4/TiO2 employed under comparable conditions (21 % vs. 63 %). Moreover, the resin-based catalyst also suffered from rapid and irreversible deactivation (as such a catalyst cannot be regenerated by calcination). From the data presented in Fig. 5(c), it is seen that similar to the trends observed in batch mode both conversion and HMF selectivity/yield as well as HMF productivity increased with increasing reaction temperature from 150 °C to 180 °C at constant WHSV. However, considering the poor stability of NbOPO4/TiO2 in sub-critical water, at temperatures > 180 °C, reaction temperatures above 180 °C were not investigated as temperatures > 180 °C are shown to cause severe degradation of the active NbOPO4 phase with substantial loss of PO4 functionality (see above). The plots of fructose conversion and HMF selectivity vs. weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) at 180 °C suggest 10–16 h−1 to be the optimum range of WHSV corresponding to a short residence time of 3.7–6 min for achieving best performance in terms of overall HMF productivity; further, increase of WHSV (shorter residence time) results in reduction of HMF productivity while the use of lower WHSV (longer residence time) led to formation humins and unknown by-products identical to the trends observed in batch mode (Fig. 5(d) and Fig. 4(a-b)). To further confirm the long-term durability of NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst, it was also subjected to multiple regeneration cycles (calcination at 500 °C for 5 h) after performing catalytic fructose dehydration at 150 °C, 9.74 h−1 and 20 bar (low activity or kinetic regime). The data presented in Fig. 6(a-b) shows that similar to the trends in batch operation, the catalyst (palletized) could regain its original activity upon calcination in air at 500 °C during three successive regeneration cycles confirming the robustness and excellent stability/durability of the developed TiO2 supported NbOPO4 catalyst under operational conditions in subcritical water. The slight loss in activity of the powdered catalyst could be attributed to loss of fine powders during reaction and/or the regenerative treatment steps. Furthermore, to verify the durability of NbOPO4/TiO2 under the optimum performance window (Table 3 and Fig. 5(d)), we further examined the long-term performance of NbOPO4/TiO2 at WHSV 10.5 and 12 h−1 at 180 °C with intermediate regeneration, the data presented in Fig. 6(c) shows that after initial induction period of ca. 6–9 h the catalyst could maintain steady performance with stable HMF yield/productivity during 80 h time on stream (with intermittent regeneration at 35 h time on stream), confirming the suitability of the developed TiO2 supported NbOPO4 catalyst for intensified HMF production in a FBR using the environmentally benign dimethyl carbonate-water biphasic system. For the sake of comparison, we also evaluated the feasibility of employing other water soluble C6 substrates such as glucose and 1:1 (wt/wt) glucose:fructose mixture as alternative feedstock for continuous HMF production in FBR the results of which are included in Table 3 and Fig. 6(d). Additionally, to evaluate the impact of feedstock on catalyst, regenerability studies were also performed using NbOPO4/TiO2 (pellets) with intermittent regeneration after deactivation with each feed (Fig. 6(d)). The results summarized in Table 3 and Fig. 6(d), show that similar to the findings in batch, glucose and glucose-fructose mixture were less reactive requiring elevated reaction temperatures and longer residence time (WHSV 6.1 h−1 vs. 10.87 h−1) to reach total sugar conversion level ∼60 %. Further, when using glucose, the HMF selectivity dropped to 55 %, while for glucose-fructose mixture and fructose the HMF selectivity was ca. 65 % and 85 % respectively, at a similar conversion level (Table 3 and Fig. 6(d)). Further, from Fig. 6(d) it is clearly seen that use of different C6 feedstock didn’t negatively impact the overall reusability/regenerability of the catalyst, this being consistent with its versatility and diverse substrate scope. However, it is also worth highlighting herein that when using neat glucose as the substrate, catalyst fouling due to humin build up was substantially faster which led to accelerated reactor clogging maximum time on stream of 10 h only (Fig. 6(d) and Figure S7, supporting information). In contrast when using fructose and 1:1 (wt/wt) glucose:fructose mixture as substrate under identical conditions, no reactor clogging was observed during extended operation time (time on stream 32–60 h) attributed mainly to the suppression of humin forming reactions with the ketohexose rich feedstocks (Fig. 6(d)). Overall, our experimental findings in FBR are consistent with the trends obtained in batch mode and consistent with the role of limiting glucose to fructose isomerization step in the production of HMF from C6 aldoses such as glucose. 3.3 Spent catalyst characterization Finally, to further substantiate the claims of experimentally observed catalytic performance of NbOPO4/TiO2 material, the spent, regenerated-spent NbOPO4/TiO2 was extensively characterized by the different analytical techniques discussed above. As shown in Fig. 7(a), the regenerated-spent materials exhibited the characteristic peaks of crystalline NbOPO4 phase consistent with the observed stability and reusability of trends. The TGA patterns of spent material recovered from FBR after 35 h time on stream at 180 °C exhibited an additional weight loss between 300 and 600 °C, attributed to the carbonization of physisorbed organic/humin like impurities (fouling), a similar weight loss event between 300 and 600 °C was also visible for catalyst recovered from batch reactor at different time intervals which was more significant for 2 h sample supporting role of residence/contact time in increasing catalyst fouling (Fig. 7(b)) and also consistent with the optical images of catalyst (taken at different stages) showing visible darkening of catalyst with increased residence time (Figure S4(a), supporting information). Interestingly, humin buildup on catalyst in 2 h was also found to be dependent on nature of support and considerably higher for SiO2 (SBA-15) and ZrO2 based catalyst than the TiO2 based one, which indicate the crucial role of the support in governing catalyst performance and HMF selectivity (Figure S4(a), supporting information). Nevertheless, this weight loss region completely disappeared in the regenerated NbOPO4/TiO2 material with recovery of original catalytic performance consistent with the effective regeneration of such catalysts upon calcination in air at 500 °C for 5–6 h (Fig. 7(b) and Fig. 2(d)). Similar results were also obtained from FT-IR and Raman measurements whereupon identical patterns were recorded for both pristine and spent-regenerated NbOPO4/TiO2 materials indicative of the presence of characteristic PO4 vibrations and consistent with the presence of active and acidic NbOPO4 phase in the spent catalytic material (Fig. 1(d) and Figure S8, supporting information). Examination of morphological features of spent-regenerated catalysts by SEM (Fig. 7(c) and Figure S2, supporting information) and corresponding micro-elemental (Nb, P, Ti and O) mapping by EDX revealed no change in either morphology or elemental distributions, which is consistent with the experimentally observed trends of reusability and stability of the developed catalysts. Further examination of spent-regenerated materials with TEM revealed a non-porous structure similar to its pristine form comprising of sphere-rod shaped particles (Fig. 7(d)). Similarly, the HRTEM images of spent-regenerated NbOPO4/TiO2 also revealed the characteristic lattice fringes with d spacing of 0.32 nm and 0.35 nm corresponding to the (200) and (101) planes of NbOPO4 and anatase TiO2 phase (Figure S9, supporting information), consistent with the findings XRD and XPS measurements (see below) and in strong support of the experimentally observed robustness and stability trends of these catalysts (Sections 3.1 and 3.2). XPS analysis of spent-regenerated catalysts recovered from batch as well as FBR operated under optimized conditions indicated the presence of Nb, P, Ti and O elements on the surface with P/Nbratio ∼1 (Fig. 7(e)). Moreover, we also observed no changes in the high resolution Nb3d and P2p XPS peaks in and the spent materials, consistent with the presence of a highly stable crystalline NbOPO4 phase with Q2 and Q3 type tetrahedral phosphates in the developed catalytic material (Figure S1(b), supporting information and Fig. 7(f)). The XPS data was also consistent with the results of ICP-MS indicating absence of Nb, Ti leaching and marginal P leaching incurred during the initial induction period attributed to the loss of weakly adsorbed phosphates from the catalyst surface. Overall, systematic post mortem examination of spent-regenerated catalysts revealed no major morphological or compositional changes in NbOPO4/TiO2 material under reaction conditions which confirming the exceptional stability of developed catalytic materials in sub-critical (hot-pressurized-liquid) water at temperatures upto 180 °C in 20 bar pressure. 3.4 Discussion and future prospective When compared to solid acid catalysts reported in prior art for HMF production from concentrated sugars in FBR, our catalytic system offers several advantages including (i) high HMF productivity, (ii) longer stability (longer time on stream, upto 30 h), (iii) catalyst-regenerability and (iv) ability to work with highly concentrated sugar solutions in an environmentally benign biphasic system ( Table 4). Another major advantage of the catalyst was the presence of only 10–20 % Nb, which reduces the high cost associated with the usage of rare metal (Nb). While the developed catalysts were ineffective for conversion of neat glucose (C6 aldose) in FBR (due to accelerated reactor clogging), it could be employed for direct conversion of highly concentrated fructose rich feedstocks (1:1 (wt/wt) glucose:fructose mixtures) and fructose in FBR with high throughput for time on stream (>30 h). Most importantly NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst could regain 100 % of its original performance (activity and HMF selectivity) following regeneration by intermittent calcination at 500 °C, which was attributed to the presence of a highly crystalline NbOPO4 phase with robust Q2 and Q3 type tetrahedral phosphate linkages. This was unlike the bulk phase porous and amorphous NbOPO4 catalysts reported in literature, which show substantial (ca. 20–25 %) irreversible activity loss following regeneration (attributed mainly to crystallization induced of porosity, surface area and acidity losses) [58–60]. Similarly, while previously reported phosphated TiO2 catalysts have shown good-excellent performance for direct conversion of diluted (0.1 M) glucose (affording upto 72 % HMF selectivity during multiple regeneration cycles with time on stream 8 h for each cycle) in a slug-flow FBR in a 4:1 (v/v) 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (MTHF)-water biphasic system, its performance dropped considerably when using a more concentrated (1 M) glucose stream as substrate. Additionally, the increase in glucose concentration also accelerated the rate of deactivation (activity loss of ca. 15 % vs. 29 % after 5 h time on stream with 0.1 vs. 1 M substrate, respectively) and caused irreversible loss of performance substantially limiting the utility of such catalysts, which limits applicability of such catalysts [27]. This benchmarking clearly shows the superiority of developed catalyst and proposed solvent systems for intensified HMF production in continuous flow FBR. Moreover, considering the ability of the proposed catalyst to convert 1:1 (v:v) glucose:fructose mixtures and to some extent glucose to HMF directly in FBR, its applicability could be most likely extended also to high fructose corn syrup as well as industrial grade corn syrup with incorporation of as additional isomerization reactor upstream to the FBR. Another major advantages of developed catalytic system was its ability to work with an environmentally benign dimethyl carbonate-water biphasic system and use of low aqueous:organic ratio 1 (v/v) which is expected to increase overall HMF productivity and ease of HMF recovery (Table 4), the only drawbacks of reported catalytic system was limited HMF selectivity in organic layer (50 % of total selectivity) and poor activity at temperatures 150 °C and lower (attributed mainly to the presence of moderately acidic NbOPO4 sites and selection of water soluble carbonate ester as solvent) which we are attempting to improve through judicious tuning of solvent systems e.g. use of multicomponent solvent systems (ongoing). Furthermore, using the productivity values as a reference (Tables 2 and 4) E factor and process mass intensity (PMI) were estimated to be 0.57 and 2.03 assuming solvent and water recovery at 70 % conversion and 96 % HMF selectivity in batch. In flow these values were slightly inferior ranging between 3.12 and 2.14 for E factor and 4.15–3.10 for PMI mainly due to the moderate-low single pass sugar conversion achievable with good HMF selectivity. However, such parameters should be used cautiously as these values do not consider loss of organic solvents, and solvent usage in downstream steps that may be required for purification of HMF obtained [61]. 4 Conclusions We have developed a number of highly acidic NbOPO4 supported TiO2 materials with excellent stability in sub-critical (hot-pressurized-liquid) water (upto 180 °C at 20 bar pressure). In terms of acidity, with acidic strength comparable to the bulk phase NbOPO4 and low to moderate concentration of acidic sites (0.11–0.52 mmolH +g−1 and tunable Brønsted/Lewis acidity), they outperformed bulk NbOPO4 in terms of cost while benchmark commercial sulfated resins in terms of durability/stability and regenerability. These acidic materials were demonstrated to be excellent catalysts for selective conversion of C6 carbohydrates to HMF in an environmentally benign 1:1 (v/v) dimethyl carbonate-water solvent system in batch as well as flow (fixed-bed reactor). The unique stability and regenerability of developed catalytic material were attributed to the presence of a highly crystalline NbOPO4 phase with Q2 and Q3 type phosphates stabilized on a robust TiO2 framework. Owing to these unique properties, these TiO2 based acidic catalyst could enable continuous HMF production (productivity of 6–27.3 kgHMFkgCat −1day−1) from highly concentrated (35 wt%) fructose, glucose and glucose:fructose mixtures in a micro fixed-bed reactor (FBR) in high selectivity (53–85 %) under industrially relevant conditions (residence time 3–10 min, 150–180 °C and 20 bar). Furthermore, our experimental findings also revealed the important role of organic extracting solvents in modulating catalyst acidic properties by virtue of proton solvation, which in turn influenced HMF yield/selectivity and among the extracting solvents tested polar aprotic ketonic solvents and carbonate ester with good aqueous miscibility were found to be the most effective. coredata.dc:description: NbOPO4 supported TiO2 materials were demonstrated to be excellent catalysts for selective conversion of C6-carbohydrates to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural in an environmentally benign dimethyl carbonate-water solvent system. The materials presented high activity and excellent stability in sub-critical water conditions (upto 180 °C and 20 bar), enabling continuous 5-hydroxymethylfurfural production from highly concentrated sugars (35 wt% fructose, glucose and glucose:fructose mixtures) in a micro fixed-bed reactor. The high catalytic activity (6–27.3 KgHMFKgCat −1day−1) and good-to-excellent HMF selectivity (55–91 %) and exceptional hydrolytic stability and regenerability observed under process conditions was attributed to a highly crystalline NbOPO4 phase with Q2 and Q3 phosphates stabilized on a TiO2 framework with tunable acidity (0.11–0.52 mmolH +g−1 and Brønsted/Lewis ratio) and acidic strength comparable to bulk-NbOPO4. Furthermore, our experiments also revealed the importance of organic solvents in modulating catalyst acidic properties, particularly the strength of Brønsted acid sites which, in turn, influenced the HMF productivity.
